name: Royal Birkdale Championship Golf
description:
One of Britain's great golf courses is recreated in this early sports simulation. Like Ocean's other early licensed sports title Daley Thompson's Decathlon, the game is split into two individually-loaded parts, with the front 9 on side 1 of the cassette and the back 9 on side 2.

Shot direction is selected by typing a compass direction value from 0 to 360, before choosing from the 10 clubs available, which include a sand iron and 2 drivers which can only be used on the tee or fairway. After this you can choose the relative percentage weight of the shot. A random wind effect can be switched on or off, affecting the game's difficulty. The release of the shot must be timed to set the level of draw and fade.

Once you reach the green you will have to consider the strength of the slope. Putting involves holding the P key to start the pace meter rising, then press it again to set the final pace of the shot.

The game starts by asking the player for wind direction. It's not compulsory and if used makes the game that bit harder
The start of the game. The screen is a little confusing because its not to scale. The player must press ENTER to commence play
Each approach shot is played the same way. First the player sets the direction of the shot in degrees, 0 - 360
Next the club is selected. If the player chooses an incorrect club the game will still play the shot but the ball will not move and the player is still charged with taking a stroke
Then the strength of the shot is chosen
With all the information entered the player presses ENTER and the character swings his club and takes the shot
Here the shot did not go so well
Much later and the ball is on the fairway near the green
Once on the green the game changes slightly.
The player is prompted for direction, 0 / 360 degrees is the top of the screen. The green has a left/right slope graded 8.
The player is also prompted for  strength. They are not prompted for a club because they are putting.
A little graphic shows the putter swing across from left to right as the stroke is played
